awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Connecting Women Faculty in Geotechnical Engineering - Thriving in a Networked World
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on professional networking outcomes among faculty in the geotechnical engineering community which will lead to broader impacts for the nation by improving retention, advancement and scientific collaboration of especially female geotechnical engineering faculty.  Networking improvements will be facilitated by developing a cohesive intellectual community that provides access to mentoring, novel information and new resources, as well as collaboration partners.  Using an intervention into the existing - largely disconnected - scientific community, female faculty will participate in networking workshops, as well as pre- and post-intervention surveys to understand their current networking needs, improvement of their networking abilities over time, and the impact their network ties have on academic collaboration.  The goal of the intervention process is to lower isolation of female faculty in geotechnical engineering by creating and sustaining a supportive national network that drives career success in academia.

This project will apply social network analysis and professional development activities to improve networking and collaboration among geotechnical engineering faculty in order to bridge the geographical distance and connectivity gaps faced especially by female geotechnical engineering faculty.  Building on past efforts of NSF and others, the project will create a network that fosters active tie creation and provides access to collaboration opportunities among geotechnical engineering faculty in the U.S.  The intervention into the existing network combines face-to-face networking meetings and virtual networking practices to increase collaboration opportunities.  The core challenges are: (a) how to sustain the attention network, (b) how to maintain strong connections among female faculty in their immediate professional environments and, (c) how to create weak ties that will help them in situations where their strong ties are unable to provide the social support, collaboration and information that they need.  The outcomes of the research will improve the faculty's understanding of the importance of networking, provide opportunities for sustaining collaborative connections with colleagues across the nation, and equip participants with the knowledge and skills to collaborate in a networked world.  The summative evaluation, including a before and after social network analysis, will evaluate the effectiveness of the purposeful interventions into the existing network of mostly weak ties among geotechnical women faculty and recommend promising practices for use in other disciplines where women face similar challenges.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to study and advance the position of women in geotechnical engineering. The overall goal was to create an enduring network of geotechnical engineering faculty, both women and men, to improve representation, retention, and advancement of female faculty. The project built on past efforts to create a geotechnical faculty network that fosters career success and resilience through networking, collaboration, and mentorship.

Two separate but related initiatives shared the goal of creating a community of women in geotechnical engineering: (1) two workshops offered a forum for female geotechnical faculty to meet and learn tools and skills to advance their careers while connecting, sharing, and thinking about the field; and (2) seed grants enabled faculty to practice what they learned in the workshops.

The workshops included 50-60% of US geotechnical female faculty and included presentations by NSF program directors, area experts in social network theory, education, and geotechnical engineering, who shared experiences and tools for building successful professional networks and collaborative projects. Surveys after both workshops indicated 90% of attendees viewed the experience favorably. Twenty-one faculty attended both workshops, and 12 later applied for seed grant funding, demonstrating that faculty took concrete actions to enhance their networks, begin or reestablish collaborations, and acquire mentors.

Small seed grants were an essential tool to enable long-distance networking, especially for junior faculty. It was this material support that separates this project from previous efforts to support women in the field. By meeting faculty where they were and providing funding for them to perform research to enhance their own careers, participants’ careers were strengthened.  Thirty-two small grants were awarded to faculty at 29 institutions, with 87 total collaborators. This number is a significant dataset, because it constitutes roughly 21% of the US geotechnical engineering faculty community.  This project demonstrates the effectiveness of seed funding in promoting collaboration and mentoring among junior faculty and leading to greater reported levels of confidence and self-efficacy. Seed grant recipients also experienced financial success, with approximately 50% of seed grant projects obtaining additional grants from institutional, state or federal sources.

During the project, the investigators built the first national database of geotechnical faculty.  By collecting and providing access to demographic and other data, the discipline can evaluate itself, and measure progress and changes with time.  Overall gender parity within geotechnical engineering is roughly average for engineering. Women comprise 18% of tenured and tenure-track US faculty. Total faculty numbers grew from 326 to 400 between 2016 and 2021, but female faculty remain 18% of geotechnical faculty in 2021.  Male faculty are more likely to be promoted to full professor, with 57% of male and 41% of female faculty, respectively, at that rank in 2021.Women faculty are more likely to be institutionally isolated, with 56% of women the only geotechnical faculty at their institution, and geographically dispersed.

To measure whether demographic changes (i.e., diversity) for female faculty are represented in awards and distinguished lectures (i.e., inclusion), we collected data from the ASCE Geo-Institute, NSF, and universities where distinguished lectures are hosted. While women have made incredible contributions to geotechnical engineering, these achievements are largely unrecognized by the overall field.  Women receive national awards at a disproportionately low rate, comprising only 9% of Geo-Institute awards and 7% of distinguished lectures over the past 30 years. In contrast, when women are peer-reviewed by their colleagues in NSF panels, as with CAREER awards, women significantly outperform their male counterparts, garnering 50% of geotechnical CAREER awards since 1995.

Over the 30-plus years of efforts to improve the field’s gender parity, themes of networking, collaboration, and mentorship have remained strong and relevant. Networking and collaboration are critical elements for establishing a thriving community. At this point we cannot claim that women in geotechnical engineering are thriving; but a foundation has been laid, connecting women in the field, and providing necessary tools and training to continue the process of building towards equity.

The unequal state of women in the field must be a focus of action at the national level.  Professional organizations, including the Geo-Institute, United States University Council for Geotechnical Education and Research, and Deep Foundations Institute should track and publish data relating to the demographics of their awards, their nominations, and leadership. Based on our experience with the benefits of seed grants to junior faculty’s career advancement, we suggest that these three organizations, along with NSF, continue to offer seed grants in support of new collaborations and networks that pursue gender parity within the field in academia and industry.

In our experience with this project, we have learned that to build a thriving and networked community, efforts must combine elements of networking, collaboration, and mentoring for a strong community. These efforts must be continuous and ongoing and require active material engagement from individuals and institutions—it is a whole-of-field effort.
